The nature of fox orientation to the magnetic North pole could also be an instinct to turn away from the sunlight when jumps for the prey. The shade of the fox must not reach the prey animal, so the fox also has a lower position when detecting. And the same experiences during the night could explain the position of the moon and moonlight.
